data.event: A judge ruled Monday that Columbia taxpayers owe design firm Stevens & Wilkinson money for a publicly funded hotel the city never built.

event.title: Two weeks ago, city attorneys rejected

data.event: Two weeks ago, city attorneys rejected a $1.6 million settlement offer from Stevens & Wilkinson, saying the two entities never had a contract.

event.title: Monday, Circuit Court Judge Casey Manning ruled

data.event: Monday, Circuit Court Judge Casey Manning ruled the city did have a contract with Stevens & Wilkinson but did not rule if or how much money the city had to pay.
Kathleen McDaniel, an attorney with Callison Tighe & Robinson, which represents the city, said Monday night she had not had time to review the order and declined to comment.

event.title: said John Nichols, past president of the S.C. Trial Lawyers Association, now

data.event: Manning’s order, known as a partial summary judgment, is rare for a plaintiff, the party who brings the lawsuit, said John Nichols, past president of the S.C. Trial Lawyers Association, now known as the S.C. Association for Justice.
In 2003, the city decided it would build and operate a hotel across from the Columbia Metropolitan Convention Center.

event.title: April 2004, after considerable public opposition to the project, City Council voted

data.event: However, in April 2004, after considerable public opposition to the project, City Council voted to give $4.5 million for a private developer — Bo Aughtry — to build the hotel, a Hilton, which opened in August 2007.

event.title: 2005, the four companies that had worked

data.event: In 2005, the four companies that had worked on the public hotel project sued the city, saying the city’s memorandum of understanding was a contract, and by going with a privately developed hotel, the city broke that contract.
Monday’s ruling does not affect the status of the other companies; their portion of the lawsuit is still pending.

event.title: three months on the project, Stevens & Wilkinson said

data.event: In July 2003, after working three months on the project, Stevens & Wilkinson said they were stopping their work until the city could borrow the money to pay for the hotel.

event.title: the hotel project for $650,000 through Oct. 15, 2003

data.event: Stevens & Wilkinson offered to continue working on the hotel project for $650,000 through Oct. 15, 2003, and $75,000 a week after that.

City Council members approved this deal, and on Dec. 13, 2003, paid Stevens & Wilkinson $697,084.79 — which lead Manning to write: “Thus the three tenants of contract have been established: offer, acceptance and valuable consideration.”
